snippet: While the United States economy is performing relatively well, the nation has fared worse than six of the nine countries surveyed by the Bureau of Labor Statistics in job gains.
abstract: Bureau Labor of Statistics analysis reveals that contrary to widespread view that United States is island of relative prosperity in global sea of economic torpor, employment in several other nations has bounced back more quickly;  overall employment in US remains 2.1 percent below where it was at the end of 2007; over same period, between December 2007 and March 2013, number of jobs was up 8.1 percent in Australia; Germany,  biggest economy in troubled euro zone, has managed a 5.8 percent gain in employment.

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Catherine Rampell, Annie Lowrey and Binyamin Appelbaum.

lead_paragraph: While the United States economy is performing relatively well, the nation has fared worse than six of the nine countries surveyed by the Bureau of Labor Statistics in job gains.

headline.seo: Employment in U.S. Lags Where It Was in 2007
headline.main: Many Rival Nations Surge Past the U.S. in Adding New Jobs
headline.print_headline: Several Rivals Surge Past U.S. In Adding Jobs
